Subject: Re: [neat] Creating 3D Objects with CPPNs and Deep Learning

From: Logan Streondj <streondj@...>

-----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----
Hash: SHA1

Hi Lehman,

My question is:
Can you evolve DNNs with NEAT?

If yes, what are the differences from evolving ordinary NNs?

p.s. I liked the mushroom, very realistic.

Thanks,
Logan

On 16-05-16 07:31 PM, lehman.154@... [neat] wrote:
> 
> 
> Sebastian Risi, Jeff Clune, and I are happy to announce our new 
> paper to appear at the International Conference on Compuational 
> Creativity, titled "Creative Generation of 3D Objects with Deep 
> Learning and Innovation Engines."
> 
> 
> http://joellehman.com/lehman_iccc2016.pdf
> 
> 
> 
> An interesting question is if the advances in deep learning that 
> have proved so powerful for directed learning can also aid 
> computational creativity. Using deep learning for creativity is 
> challenging because creativity offers no supervised error function
>  from which loss gradients can be differentiated and propagated 
> backwards through a neural network.
> 
> 
> The main idea in this work is to highlight one significant 
> dimension of creative potential opened by combining evolutionary 
> computation with deep learning. The general insight is that deep 
> learning is effective at creating high-level representations from 
> raw high-dimensional data, while evolutionary algorithms can make 
> use of indirect encodings and non-differentiable computation. One 
> particular possibility enabled by this kind of combination is to 
> create content *across modalities*. For example, a deep network 
> trained in one modality (e.g. 2D images) can be leveraged to create
> content in another modailty (e.g. 3D objects).
> 
> 
> This paper's main result (which builds on the innovation engines 
> work Jeff presented at last year's GECCO) is that the 
> endlessforms.com EC encoding of 3D objects can be applied to 
> extract knowledge from a deep network trained to recognize 2D 
> images, thereby producing interesting and recognizable 3D objects 
> (which can then be 3D printed). We use a rendering engine to 
> produce multiple 2D snapshots of a 3D object (represented by a 
> CPPN), and then use selection pressure from a trained 
> object-recognition deep network to drive the MAP-ELITES EA towards 
> recognizable 3D objects.
> 
> 
> Given the surprising potential of deep networks, it's interesting 
> to explore the possible synergies between the strengths of EC and 
> those of deep learning. In particular, there may be interesting 
> ways to leverage the learned high-level representations of deep 
> learning to do things that might not be currently possibility with
>  EC alone. If nothing else, the paper has a lot of fun images of 
> evolved 3D objects (some of which are 3D printed) that might be 
> worth a look!
> 
> 

- -- 
Logan Streondj,
A dream of Gaia's future.
http://joyfullifestyle.ca
